documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology services records
summary: A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records documenting daily clinical observations, interventions, and a suicide risk assessment for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 10-24, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The records detail his complaints about conditions, his psychological state, and the incident on July 23 where he was found with a string around his neck, leading to a suicide watch. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons clinical intervention reports from July 24-28, 2019, detailing Jeffrey Epstein's psychological status and adjustment while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It covers his removal from suicide watch after an incident involving marks on his neck, his placement on psychological observation, his complaints about SHU conditions, and his repeated claims of having no memory of the neck injury incident.

events.title: Initial Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein is seen for a psychological observation contact in the hospital area. He voices numerous complaints about conditions and his upcoming bail hearing.

events.title: Found with String Around Neck / Suicide Watch Initiated
events.description: At about 2 AM, Epstein is found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He is placed on Suicide Watch. The origin of the string is unclear.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: PsyD conducts a formal Suicide Risk Assessment on Epstein. He denies memory of the string incident, but a log notes he told staff his cellmate tried to kill him. He is assessed with a moderate acute suicide risk.

events.title: Suicide Watch Ended
events.description: Epstein is removed from Suicide Watch after approximately 31 hours. He continues to deny suicidal ideation but expresses fear for his safety regarding his previous cellmate.

events.title: Bail Hearing / Denial
events.description: Epstein references a bail hearing on Monday, July 15, and later notes he was recently denied bail, which is listed as a dynamic risk factor in his assessment.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident in SHU
events.description: An incident occurred in the SHU involving Epstein and his cellmate, resulting in marks/scabs on Epstein's neck from what was alleged to be a bed sheet or rope. Epstein claims no memory of the event.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is stepped down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation after assessment. He denies suicidality, citing his legal case and having a 'wonderful life'.

events.title: Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein is placed and remains on Psychological Observation in the hospital area, with daily psychology checks, due to concerns about his adjustment and the unexplained neck injury.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on Suicide Watch.
Epstein claimed no memory of the string incident but, according to a staff log, told watching staff that his cellmate tried to kill him.
Psychological assessments consistently noted Epstein denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, both before and after the string incident.

Epstein expressed numerous complaints about jail conditions, including his orange jumpsuit, desire for single-cell housing, lack of property, and fear for his safety if returned with his previous cellmate.

A suicide risk assessment on July 23 concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Moderate' due to the unclear nature of the incident, his high-profile case, and lack of family connections, despite many protective factors.
Epstein sustained marks/scabs around his neck while in the SHU but repeatedly claimed to have no memory of how the injury occurred.
Epstein expressed fear and dissatisfaction with being housed in the SHU, citing noise, smells, perceived danger from MS-13 gang members, and restrictions that hindered work on his legal case.
Clinical staff consistently assessed Epstein's acute suicide risk as low, with him adamantly denying any desire to kill himself because he was invested in fighting his legal case.
Epstein reported that his cellmate had called him a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him on the day of the neck injury incident.
The documents show a pattern of Epstein receiving daily legal visits and being primarily concerned with his comfort, legal access, and medication (Colace for constipation).
